head.title: No Arcade, No Games (At Least Near School)

meta.content: Technology; Education; New York and Region

hedline.hl1: No Arcade, No Games (At Least Near School)

abstract.p: Community Board 7 committee rejects application by Mireybi Vega Game Room to build video arcade in basement of apartment building opposite Booker T Washington Junior High School in upper Manhattan; Cybergames store on Broadway near 102nd Street has sidestepped city regulations by connecting home systems like Nintendo to a television set and charging by the hour; photo (M)

block.p: An application to build a video arcade opposite Booker T. Washington Junior High School, on West 107th Street, is not scoring points with local residents, who would like to zap the arcade as a major distraction and neighborhood nuisance. A committee of Community Board 7 has already voted against the application by Mireybi Vega Game Room to the Department of Consumer Affairs.

The location of the proposed arcade -- the basement of an apartment building now occupied by an informal social club -- has been associated with drug dealing and prostitution, according to the local Business Improvement District.

Washington Junior High School, on West 107th Street, is not scoring points with local residents, who would like to zap the arcade as a major distraction and neighborhood nuisance. A committee of Community Board 7 has already voted against the application by Mireybi Vega Game Room to the Department of Consumer Affairs.

The location of the proposed arcade -- the basement of an apartment building now occupied by an informal social club -- has been associated with drug dealing and prostitution, according to the local Business Improvement District.
''We can only assume, given what's already there, that the whole thing is problematic,'' said Melanie Radley, co-chairwoman of the board's uniformed services committee.

Under city regulations, a video arcade cannot be located within 200 feet of a public school. The opposition of community boards and the labyrinth of regulations foils all but the best-organized and connected applicants, according to people in the industry. Most of the city's arcades are in Times Square and Coney Island.
Even as resistance builds to an arcade on West 107th Street, one entrepreneur a few blocks away has discovered a way to get around the city's complex licensing process.

At Cybergames, a small store on Broadway near 102nd Street, a sleeker version of the old arcade has been born. By connecting home systems like Nintendo 64 and Sega Dreamcaster to a television set and a counter that charges by the hour, Cybergames has attracted a steady flow of customers, mostly youngsters stopping by after school. Because the games are not considered arcade machines, the store can exceed the limit of four units without obtaining a license.
The idea has proved so popular, a similar store, called Game Room, opened a year ago on West 99th Street.

The stores neither look nor sound like traditional arcades, which are typically dark and noisy hangouts for teenagers. At Cybergames, children as young as 5 sit surrounded by siblings, friends, baby sitters and parents, all under the watchful gaze of the owner, Danny Ahn, and his employees.
''The main reason the city requires a license is because arcades pull in bad traffic,'' Mr. Ahn said. By contrast, Cybergames offers constant supervision of children.
''And believe me, kids are crazy about games,'' Mr. Ahn said. ''If I tell them to shut up, they will shut up.''
